Posts.Content: Thank you both. X I gave phoned unit and waiting for a call back. Feeling ridiculous but can kind of see the funny side!
Posts.Title: Nits

Posts.Content: I coldcapped with my first FEC chemo 11 days ago. I have been resisting washing and brushing it in order to try and help it stay in. I've woken up to discover I have nits ( kids don't seem to have them but will be rechecking tonight!) Now trying to decide whether to blitz them with a chemical spray or use the oil and nit comb. Either way does not sound good for my hair I feel like screaming!!!! I think I am clutching at straws but anyone have any thoughts?
Posts.Title: Nits

Posts.Content: The unit said I could use a chemical treatment if I wanted but either way needed to comb my hair. So I opted for the NittyGritty oil I use for the kids and nit combed it. I have come to the conclusion that my hair will be what it will be and I cannot get stressed about it staying in anymore. To be honest, it gave me a laugh this week :-))))
Posts.Title: Nits

Posts.Content: This happened to me and it was worth the wait in my case. The MRI picked up other problem areas that the scans/mammograms didn't so I ended up the right surgery first time. If I hadn't had the MRI, I would have gone on to need further surgeries later. Hopefully the MRI will just confirm what they already know but it is good to know they are being thorough. Good luck x
Posts.Title: Surgery pushed back a week, surgeon wants MRI beforehand

Posts.Content: Thank you x I'm going to sleep on it (if I can!).
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Had my appointment with my surgical consultant and bcn yesterday. Finished my expansion, which still has a crease in it but I'm getting used to it. He talked through all of my results and put my mind at rest about the decisions to be made. Feel a bit lost as now not seeing him for 4 months when we will discuss reconstruction. He has been easy to talk through during this horrendous process and I feel like I am starting again now with the oncologist whom I don't feel comfortable with. Maybe that will change with the appointment I have with him next Tuesday.   Feeling remarkably calm and quiet - something I have never been! I am determined to get through all this as it is the best chance I have of getting over all this, but not sure I will cope. My new motto is to take one day at a time
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Hi! Saw my oncologist again on Tuesday and this time things were more positive. We discussed treatment -' 6 cycles of FEC75, then herceptin starts 4-6 weeks later. He has told me I can go on holiday first (we have one booked at the end of May) and says there is no risk in me delaying the start. I feel remarkably calm about what is to come largely due to the fact that for the first time in 3 months everything is clear. Waiting for my start date but feel I know have a couple of weeks to get prepared and then a week to have fun with all my family before it starts.  Dash - I have said I will take each step as it comes. My mother-in-law had leukaemia 12 years ago and only had 2 of 6 cycles of chemo as it made her so ill. They gave her 12 months and 12 years on is fitter and healthier than all of us! Good luck with the rads. Funda - they were going to do the Oncotype test but as I am HER2 positive it became irrelevant. I know now chemo is the right way to go ( I was subconsciously leaning that way anyway). I want to do all I can to prevent this Happening again. As a family we have had a rough 3 months and while I would like to move on, I think this is the way to try and prevent it happening again. It is 5 months but hopefully a nice summer will allow us to have lots of fun with the paddling pool in the garden and me sleeping in the shade on a sun lounger!!!! Failing that grandparents/aunts for days out and a large supply of dvd's ha ha! Silvercloud xx
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: I know at only I can make the decision but I need to let off steam! I saw the oncologist today and even more confused.  My surgical consultant said that they highly recommended chemo and that if I were his wife he would tell her to have it. The oncologist today seemed very laid back and said it was my decision. He said I need to decide and used the predict tool. The five year stats were 90% and chemo added another 2.6%, the ten to year stats were 75% and chemo added another 7%. He gave me no guidance other than to say I was young (43) with young children and I think he was thinking I should go for chemo. I should have asked straight out but didn't think to! We are still waiting for the HER2 result on the second tumour but they are fairly positive it will be negative. Once this has come back, he has said he would get them to send off for the Oncotype dx test.  So the really ridiculous thing is, I am now thinking I should be taking the chemo to make sure all is covered and that I will forever be worried if the test comes back low and I can't have it. I don't want to have chemo but I am worried that it will come back if I don't. Logic says the Oncotype is a far better tool to use than the stats but I seem to have lost all sense!
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Than you everyone for being there and for the support. I am so grateful for it all and admire the strength everyone has. I phoned and left a message for my bcn at 7am this morning! I just said that I have no idea whether the chemo is actually being recommended and that I want to talk to someone who can help clarify. Then I can make a decision as to whether to just say yes or wait the 3 weeks for the test.  Carolyn - I hope you find the perfect holiday - Sounds ideal :-) Xx
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Carolyn - I will make a trip to M&S - love their food! I have been to the dentist and hygienist. Dentist was very supportive and gas told me I can go and see her during treatment if I am worried about anything. I also had a hair appointment on weds so had my long hair cut to just above my shoulders. Not sure if I will try the cold cap - will need to research that a bit more. Looked up Eden Hazard - there are far worse hair cuts out there!!!! Just one of the many things to contend with on this journey.  Karen - good luck with the other with the other oncologist. I'm sure mine will be okay on Tuesday. I'm relieved that all the tests are done now and it's now treatment. Right from my diagnosis in mid Feb I have had conflicting test results and been waiting for results to come back. Whilst I was upset at the HER2 result, I am relieved that the waiting is over. I was thinking of trying to delay the start as we have a family holiday booked for half term but I am now thinking I just want to get this started. I am amazed at just how strong we can be xxxx
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: I went into the appointment with the impression that chemo was highly recommended and have come out thinking this is all my decision. I don't know if they recommend it or not and I don't think I can do another 3-4 weeks of not knowing.  I feel like I have reached my breaking point and I don't know what to do. I feel very alone in all this and it is just too hard. My husband is trying to help me through this but he can't make the decision. I feel like I have been abandoned when I most needed to be guided. I wish I had asked the oncologist outright what he thought I should do but I'm not sure I would have got an answer even then. I feel like I messed the whole appointment up and now have 3 weeks before I see him again. I am frightened of chemo and all that it entails. I'm scared how it will impact all our lives and whether I can cope with the whole process. But, I am also scared that this could all happen again and that if I don't have the chemo I will spend my life waiting for this to happen again. I don't know that I can live with that.
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: I've just spoken to my bcn and, as it has been at every step of this process, I seem to be going against what they think will happen! The HER2 finally came back this morning and it is positive. So chemo and Herceptin it is. I feel upset that it is yet more but I also feel strangely relieved. I know now that chemo will definitely be a benefit and I can move forward.  Glad I didn't take the tamoxifen he presciribed today - bcn told me not to bother now. Now waiting to see oncologist again and will definitely be more direct with him :-) Thank you again so much. I have valued every comment and you have helped me not feel so alone. I'm sure I will seek out further advice on this journey but for now I wish all of you the very best and hope I can return the support xx

Posts.Content: Thank you it helped put things in to perspective.  We have the doors and windows open and it's good to feel like life is normal for a few hours. Thankfully it is a mixture of adults and kids - think 35 kids would be the end of me ha ha!!! Xx
Posts.Title: Am I mad?

Posts.Content: Ok - so this is probably the most ridiculous post but I could do with opinions. We planned a family party to celebrate both my children's birthdays for today (35 people) thinking we could put gazebos in the garden if it was wet. Well it is wet and blowing a gale so no gazebos. Am I mad thinking about having all those people in my house day 13 after chemo no 4? I feel fine but now worried about picking up bugs!! My mum has offered to do it at hers.  I've not worried about things like this at all during the chemo but the oncologists have now started talking about radiotherapy again after dismissing it and I got an appointment through yesterday to see my surgical consultant next week. It is after I had an ultrasound scan on my implant and my oncologist has asked him to see me. The radiographer said the implant was fine but I am now worried it is something else and that has thrown me completely.  This party all seems ridiculously petty now but I need to make a decision and my brain seems to have seized. Xx
Posts.Title: Am I mad?

There is a lot to deal with and you need to let it out somewhere.   I had my mastectomy 2 1/2 weeks ago and I am still learning that I have to put myself first sometimes which is something I never did before this. Posts.Title: Having a meltdown

Posts.Content: Hi I have had lots of trouble finding bras that fit well. I used to be a 34FF with Bravissimo but have gone down slightly (34F). I couldn't find any front fastening bras. I bought a number of front fastening ones from high street stores but my bcn and consultant said they weren't supportive enough. I ended up at a specialist shop that my bcn knew about and now have 2 lovely Anita bras. Did require a nearly an hours drive to get there though! Royce also do a lot of bras online..They also do a service where you if you need pockets in one of their bras that is not specifically a mastectomy one, they can sew them in for you once you have bought and tried it on for size. Not tried it myself but did look online as a possibility. Sorry I can't be more help. Hope you find what you need. Silvercloud xx
Posts.Title: BRA talk

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlercrab I had mastectomy with immediate reconstruction with an expander implant due to the fact I was having radiotherapy. My surgeon recommended it as he said that the radiotherapy could damage the implant and that any radiotherapy would affect any healthy tissue used in reconstruction.  That was last March and I am now 1 week on from having the expander out and a permanent implant put in. A much shorter operation and easier recovery. I am pleased with the result even with all the bruising I have! It's not an easy decision as we have such choice! I wish you luck on your journey. Caroline xx

Posts.Title: Question about expander top up

Posts.Content: Following my right side mastectomy 4 weeks ago, I got my detailed results of the pathology results this week in the post.  I already knew that I had a 27mm grade 2 and a 23mm grade 3 ductal. I also had widespread high grade DCIS.  The one node they took is clear. I am ER+ And so far HER2 neg but still waiting for this result on the second tumour. There are various Q /NPI/pT numbers on the report as well that mean nothing to me!! My surgical consultant told me that when they discussed the results at their multidisciplinary they agreed that  thy highly recommend I have chemotherapy. His view was, if it was his wife he would be encouraging her to have it. I now have an appointment on tuesday to see the oncologist. I am going to ask him what all these numbers mean and why they think I should have chemo. I think I want to know my prognosis as well. I am guessing that they will got through the treatment plan etc? I think I may see the oncology nurse as well but don't know I also want to find out about the cold cap - although I'm not sure if I can cope with that as well. My 8 year old daughter is distraught at the thought of me losing my hair as I 'won't be the same'! So will ask and see. can anyone recommend any other questions I should ask? I want to make sure I go as prepared as possible. My mum is coming with me as my husband has to work, so I need to be able to feedback answers to him as well!! We have a holiday booked at the end of May to the south coast with all my family (19 of us!!). Not even sure if we will be able to go now - grrr. At least I can send the kids!

I am worried I won't be able to cope with chemo but when I take a breath I realise I have coped with nearly 11 weeks of all this and I'm still here! silvercloud xxx
Posts.Title: Oncologist appointment questions to ask

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah Im 43 and my children were 8 and 10 when I was diagnosed in February. My BCN gave me two books from Breast cancer care - mummy's lump and Medikidz explain cancer. I sat them down and explain that I had cancer and that it was some body cells that had gone bad. I explained that I was being looked after by great doctors and that they would take the cells away in an. Operation.  I decided to be upfront with them and encouraged them to ask questions. I didnt want them to hear us or other people talk about it all and misunderstand.  Breastcancercare website has a good section on talking to children that may help.  www.breastcancercare.org.uk/talking-children-about-breast-cancer They will go through lots of emotions and in our family it has been a mixture of helpfulness, constantly checking me, frustration, tears, long chats late at night and making mummy laugh! I also went and spoke to my children's headteacher. She has told them there is always someone to talk to, something my 8 year old daughter has used. My 10 year old son tends to process things in his head for a while before speaking out (10 pm usually!)  I hope this helps in some small way. Please feel free to ask any questions or if you want someone to sound off to Caroline xx
